title: Dow Falls as Investors Eye ECB, Earnings; Major indexes took a step lower after the White House said President Biden tested positive for Covid-19 and had 'very mild symptoms'
text:
The benchmarks briefly turned lower after the White House said President Joe Biden, 79 years old, tested positive for Covid-19 and has "very mild symptoms." He has begun taking Paxlovid and will isolate at the White House where he will continue to "carry out all of his duties fully during that time."

In Europe, the ECB raised interest rates for the first time in more than a decade and by more than previously indicated by President Christine Lagarde, lifting the eurozone out of negative rate territory. Theeuro strengthened 0.2% against the dollar to $1.02.

The ECB faces a related challenge in convincing investors that a new policy tool can shield fragile southern European economies from the risk of spiraling borrowing costs. Particularly vulnerable is Italy, where Mario Draghi resigned Thursday as prime minister. His decision hit Italian stocks, with the FTSE MIB falling 0.9%. By comparison, the pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 inched up 0.3%.

A slew of disappointing corporate results across industries from telecommunications to airlines also weighed on the market.

AT&T shares fell 8.9% after the company lowered its 2022 target for free cash flow. Verizon Communications also fell 3.3%, among the blue-chip Dow's top decliners.

Airline stocks retreated following weak reports. United Airlines, which cautioned about the effects of higher fuel prices, fell 9.2%. American Airlines declined 7.9% after it posted a profit that fell short of analysts' expectations.

Shares of cruise lines sunk after Carnival said it would sell $1 billion of new stock. Carnival dropped 12.2%, the biggest laggard on the S&P 500. Royal Caribbean Group and Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings also saw shares fall roughly 8% and 9%, respectively.

On the upside, Tesla shares rallied 7% after reporting better-than-expected quarterly results, providing support to the tech-heavy Nasdaq. The electric vehicle maker, however, reported its first decline in quarterly profit in more than a year.

Stocks have steadied in recent weeks after a challenging first half of the year. The three major averages are on pace for gains this week and for July.

Earnings reports from companies including Netflix have given investors greater confidence to buy up beaten-down tech stocks. Nonetheless, many money managers expect more volatility ahead as the Federal Reserve keeps raising interest rates to curb inflation.

"There's a bit more optimism around the growth sector than there was a couple of months ago," said Edward Park, chief investment officer at Brooks Macdonald. "The key question is whether we have a big earnings recession heading into 2023."

Elsewhere, natural-gas prices in Europe fell 4.2% after Russia began to pump fuel through the Nord Stream pipeline to Germany at a reduced rate. Governments had been waiting to see if Moscow would restart the flow after routine maintenance, as President Vladimir Putin weaponizes energy supplies while waging war on Ukraine.

Oil prices also fell, with Brent crude shedding 2.6%. Energy stocks took a hit, with the S&P 500 energy sector dropping 3.4% and leading losses on the broad index.

On the U.S. economic front, a data release showed that weekly jobless claims came in at 251,000, a bigger rise from the previous week than economists expected.

In Asia, China's Shanghai Composite fell 1% after authorities in Shenzhen took steps to contain a coronavirus outbreak, but Japan's Nikkei 225 added 0.4%.

Write to Joe Wallace at joe.wallace@wsj.com

Dow Falls as Investors Eye ECB, Earnings
